channel.title: Internet - Digg
channel.description: Internet on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: Social Distancing Diaries: Surviving A Virtual School Day
item.description: The physical and mental challenges of quarantine are daunting enough. Add two screaming kids and teaching kindergarten to the mix? Anarchy.

item.title: Take YouTube's Dangers Seriously
item.description: The website's features can lead people unwittingly to scary places.

item.title: How Our Top Google Searches Have Changed During The Coronavirus
item.description: April 2019 was a simpler time. Americans wanted to know what a black hole was, who was playing in the Final Four and how many episodes of "Game of Thrones" there were.

item.title: Why Are We So Obsessed With Making Famous Men Our #InternetBoyfriends?
item.description: From TimothÃ©e Chalamet and Keanu Reeves to Jeff Goldblum and Donald Glover — unpacking the rise of the extremely online phenomenon.
item.kicker: FYI WE ALSO WANT THEM TO RUN US OVER WITH TRUCKS

item.title: Here's A Perfect Encapsulation Of What Every Facebook Video Looks Like These Days
item.description: From the music to the captions, this is pitch perfect.

item.title: I Bought Everything I Saw In Instagram Ads For A Month
item.description: From 3D-printed health pastilles to self-electrocuting muscle spasms, I lived how Instagram wanted me to live. Until I had to make it stop

item.title: Art Recreation Is The Only Good Instagram Challenge
item.description: Around the world, people are posing as famous portraits with toilet paper, bedsheets, drawn-on unibrows, and did we mention toilet paper?

item.title: Parents, If Your Kids Say They're Bored Have 'Em Push This Big Fun Button
item.description: Colorado's stay-at-home order has been in place since March 26 and as the parents at Colorado Public Radio can attest, the youth are getting a bit... restless.

item.title: Everyone Is Trying To Sell Medical Equipment — Even On LinkedIn
item.description: With face masks and other protective gear in short supply, speculators and pop-up brokers are finding customers on an unlikely platform.

item.title: This Massive School District's First Day Of Distance Learning Fell Apart Amid Racial Slurs, Porn
item.description: One of the largest and wealthiest school districts in America, Fairfax County, started distancing learning this week. Between racial slurs and porn, it went so poorly they had to cancel.
item.kicker: IF YOU GIVE A KID A COMPUTER

item.title: Here Are The Questions The Right's Favorite Coronavirus Truther Isn't Willing To Answer
item.description: Alex Berenson prefers not to be fact-checked.

item.title: Who's Actually Horny On Main When Everyone's Horny On Main?
item.description: As media, brands, influencers, and all your friends pivot to horny™, some are raising the bar to horny levels beyond belief.

item.title: Virtual Sex Parties Offer Escape From Isolation — If Organizers Can Find A Place To Host Them
item.description: Platforms like Zoom aren't happy about being used for NSFW purposes.
item.kicker: BOOM BOOM BOOM BOOM, I WANT YOU IN MY ZOOM

item.title: The Many Languages Missing From The Internet
item.description: English and a handful of other languages dominate the internet, but this is leaving indigenous cultures without a voice online. Now they are fighting back.

item.title: The Rise Of Zoom Breakups
item.description: The search for love continues — and so does the ending of once-promising relationships. Now, though, all this is happening via videoconference.

item.title: IT Workers At Hollywood Reporter and Billboard Vandalize Website After Getting Laid Off
item.description:
"Fat drunk and stupid is no way to go through life…
#SavingABuckAtYourExpense," the (quickly deleted) post read, in part.

item.title: This Absolutely Unhinged 'Gossip Girl' Meme Is Perfect For These Unhinged Times
item.description: Who started doing this? What is broken inside of them? We will never know and we do not care. Let's just chase the joy this meme brings.

item.title: A Chinese Live-Streamer Fell In Love. It Cost Her Her Virtual World
item.description: With thousands of followers, Shanghai live-streamer Nai Nai was a girlfriend to many, until she met Chinese internet legend Jiang Bo. Little did she know the price she would pay for her feelings

item.title: Inside The Strip Clubs Of Instagram
item.description: Going digital may be better for dancers.

item.title: Sex Work Comes Home
item.description: More of us are making and watching sexual performances online now. Fewer of us are paying.

item.title: Why Is Every Influencer Wearing A Tie-Dye Sweatsuit In Quarantine?
item.description: All the cool kids on Instagram have figured out a way to make quarantine fashion, and why is literally everyone going live on Instagram right now?

item.title: Reddit's Biggest Stock Market Forum Implodes Under Insider Trading Accusations
item.description: This week, after shocking allegations emerged about the subreddit's founder, r/WallStreetBets went dark.

item.title: I Buried My Grandfather On Zoom
item.description: The coronavirus hasn't just changed our lives. It's disrupted death —Â and the rituals that are fundamental to burial for religious families like mine.

item.title: Chance Fletcher, President Of Harvard Law School's Federalist Society Chapter, Brought A Gun To A Zoom Class
item.description: The student already has a prestigious clerkship lined up with a federal appeals court judge.

item.title: When Targeted Ads Feel A Little Too Targeted
item.description: Whether you're dealing with fertility issues, in recovery, or scared of the coronavirus.

item.title: The Viral 'Study' About Runners Spreading Coronavirus Is Not Actually A Study
item.description: Belgian researchers chose to bypass all standard science publishing protocols to publish research that has been overhyped and isn't well understood.

item.title: Quibi's Brave New World Of Reality TV Is A Magnificent Disaster
item.description: We watched all 12 of Quibi's "Unscripted" shows and learned absolutely nothing. Is that the premise?

item.title: This 'Open The Lock' Logic Puzzle Is Stumping The Internet. Can You Solve It?
item.description: In this viral logic puzzle, you have to open a lock using five numerical clues. Here's how to solve the riddle that's stumping the internet.

item.title: Quibi's Brave New World Of Reality TV Is A Magnificent Disaster
item.description: By bringing together some of the biggest celebrity names for off-beat streaming shows, Jeffrey Katzenberg's new ventture is odd and confusing.

item.title: Welcome To The Instagram Orgy: How Horniness Is Flourishing In Quarantine
item.description: From Zoom to OnlyFans, coronavirus isolation means lonely, horny people have to get creative.

item.title: How The Virus Has Changed The Way We Use The Internet, Charted
item.description: With many stuck at home during the pandemic, Americans have been spending more of their lives online. This is how our habits have changed.

item.title: The Vanishing Public Square
item.description: What happens when we can no longer march?

item.title: Quibi Reviews: Which New Series Are Worth Your Time?
item.description: Shortform streaming service Quibi launches today with 24 narrative and documentary series. We reviewed and ranked the first three episodes of each show to determine the best new series to watch, including "Nikki Fre$h," "Gayme Show," and "NightGowns."

item.title: Why Quibi Will Be A Multi-Billion Dollar Company
item.description: Short-form premium video is here to stay.

item.title: Why It Feels Like Everyone Is Hanging Out Online Without You
item.description: Social media has made it easier for us to compare ourselves to others — especially when many of us are forced to stay home.

item.title: The Hollywood Job
item.description: eBay. HP. Governor of California (well, almost). Quibi? Meg Whitman's last act is her biggest bet yet.

item.title: How Google Searches Can Help Us Find Emerging COVID-19 Outbreaks
item.description: They can also reveal symptoms that at first went undetected. I may have found a new one.

item.title: The Wild And Crazy Online Forum Tracking The Coronavirus Dead
item.description: Due to its long history and tendency toward gallows humor and infighting, alt.obituaries provides a strange, fascinating look at how COVID-19 deaths are dealt with online.

item.title: 'Zoombombing' Becomes A Dangerous Organized Effort
item.description: Zoom, the videoconferencing app, has become a target for harassment and abuse coordinated in private off-platform chats.

item.title: Dav Pilkey Is Hosting Virtual Readings And Drawing Lessons
item.description: Dav Pilkey — author and illustrator of the "Captain Underpants" and "Dog Man" book series — is also stuck at home. So he's teaming up with the Library of Congress to read to our kids and help them learn to draw some of his most beloved characters.

item.title: This Statistical Personality Test That Shows Which Fictional Characters You Are Most Similar To Is Incredibly Comprehensive
item.description: Covering 121 questions (or 28, if you're in a rush) and 400 characters, this test isn't your regular BuzzFeed personality quiz.

item.title: Is Quibi A Good Idea?
item.description: Two television writers debate whether or not the soon-to-be-launched short-form, celebrity-led streaming service will find an audience.

item.title: What Is Twitch, Anyway?
item.description: Twitch is more than a website; it's chat, audiences, streamers and community itself. (It's also the tech that makes everything work.)

item.title: A Must For Millions, Zoom Has A Dark Side — And An FBI Warning
item.description: Dennis Johnson fell victim last week to a new form of harassment known as "Zoombombing," in which intruders hijack video calls and post hate speech and offensive images such as pornography. It's a phenomenon so alarming that the FBI has issued a warning about using Zoom.

item.title: In Dr. Fauci We Stan: How The Coronavirus Leader Became A Beloved Meme
item.description: Dr. Fauci stans have created Facebook fan clubs, TikTok videos, donuts, and even prayer candles in celebration of the scientist leading the Trump White House's novel coronavirus response.

item.title: An Art Exhibit You Can Visit Without Leaving Your Couch
item.description: The creators of the Whitney Museum's New York Apartment explain how they combined thousands of listings into a website for one massive, $43.9 billion dwelling.

item.title: How Scammers Have Been Able To Send Realistic-Looking Emails From The World Health Organization To Target Online Victims
item.description: Scammers are taking advantage of the coronavirus pandemic by sending emails claiming to be from the WHO. How are they doing this?

item.title: That Viral Drone Date Guy's Story Doesn't Quite Check Out
item.description: We talked to him, and the clip might be a bit less spontaneous than advertised.

item.title: How to Improve Your Wifi Speeds When Everyone's Home
item.description: Chances are, your home internet is under a lot more strain than normal at the moment: With schools and workplaces temporarily closing all across the globe, you might well be fighting with your family or your housemates for any available bandwidth. If you want to limit buffering and maximize speeds, we've got a few tips to consider.

item.title: The Great Influencer Exodus
item.description: Instagram influencers from Naomi Davis to Arielle Charnas are ignoring orders to shelter in place, putting themselves and others at risk.
item.kicker: SHAME THE HELL OUT OF THEM
